title: Iegor Vyshnevskyi
text:
I live in South Korea with my family. Beyond academia, I enjoy practicing Hapkido, traveling, and listening to music. I am especially passionate about mentoring, cross-cultural education, and raising a bilingual (and even trilingual) child in a multicultural environment.
My professional journey spans academia, public service, and financial institutions‚Äîalways guided by the belief that banking and finance should serve the greater good both locally and globally. I began my career at the National Bank of Ukraine, contributing to financial stability efforts, including risk assessment and macroprudential policy. My academic path brought me to the KDI School of Public Policy and Management, where I refined my research skills and deepened my policy expertise.
Following the completion of my Ph.D.¬†in Public Policy, I transitioned fully into academia. I now teach economics, finance, and data science, working closely with students to develop analytical tools that inform impactful policy and business decisions. I remain dedicated to bridging the gap between academic research, real-world policy, and practical implementation.
Above all, I am deeply grateful for the extraordinary people who have shaped my path. I owe everything to the love and support of my family‚Äîmy incredible wife and daughter‚Äîwhose presence inspires me daily. I am also thankful for the sacrifices of my parents, relatives, friends, and mentors, whose unwavering belief in me continues to fuel my dedication to education, research, and using finance as a tool for positive change.

title: Teaching and Advising
text:
Throughout my academic career, I have taught courses in economics, macroeconomics, finance, and data science at both undergraduate and graduate levels. My teaching philosophy emphasizes applied learning, with a strong focus on equipping students with practical skills in financial modeling, economic policy analysis, and programming for data-driven decision-making.
I place particular importance on helping students bridge theory and practice. In my courses, students work with real-world data, learn to communicate analytical results clearly, and develop the technical competencies needed for research, policy analysis, and industry roles.

I have advised and mentored students on research projects across economics, finance, and data science. This includes guiding students through research design, empirical analysis, and the preparation of academic manuscripts. My goal is to foster critical thinking, methodological rigor, and independent problem-solving skills, preparing students for careers in academia, industry, and policy institutions.

title: Work in Progress
text:
Authors: Cory Baird, Jonathan Benchimol, Vira Vyshnevska, Iegor Vyshnevskyi, and Wook Sohn
This project explores how central bank communications influence the transmission of global financial shocks to domestic financial conditions. By identifying and quantifying central bank information effects in advanced and emerging markets, we investigate their role as a key channel in the global financial cycle.
Using high-frequency surprises around monetary policy announcements and a novel text-based measure of central bank information disclosure, we find that information effects amplify or dampen the pass-through of global shocks depending on the clarity, credibility, and independence of the central bank.
The research highlights significant heterogeneity across countries and time periods, showing that stronger institutional frameworks allow central banks to steer market expectations more effectively and buffer spillovers from global financial conditions.
Key Contributions: - Estimates the impact of central bank information effects on domestic bond yields, exchange rates, and equity markets. - Constructs a novel dataset combining monetary policy communication, financial variables, and global risk indicators. - Demonstrates the importance of communication transparency in reducing exposure to external financial shocks.
Poster:
ASSA/AEA Annual Conference (January 3‚Äì5, 2026, Philadelphia, USA)

title: Work in Progress
section: The Global Database for Central Bank Communications
text:
The Global Database for Central Bank Communications
Authors: Cory Baird, Jonathan Benchimol, Vira Vyshnevska, Iegor Vyshnevskyi, and Wook Sohn
We introduce the Global Database for Central Bank Communications (GDCBC), analyzing over 6,000+ monetary policy statements from 50 central banks worldwide. This database fills a critical research gap by providing the largest repository of standardized central bank communications.
Methodological Contributions: 1. Developing standardized text preprocessing pipelines to ensure reproducibility in NLP analysis. 2. Implementing an integrated framework for training domain-specific language models. 3. Providing a robust technical architecture for automated data collection, version control, and cloud computing.
Using this dataset, we document significant narrative convergence during major economic shocks and identify systematic patterns in global information effects across diverse economies.
Presentation:
4th IFC and Bank of Italy Workshop on ‚ÄúData Science in Central Banking‚Äù (February 18‚Äì20, 2025, Rome, Italy)

title: Iegor Vyshnevskyi
text:
Welcome! I‚Äôm Iegor Vyshnevskyi, Assistant Professor at Sogang University.
I specialize in central banking, monetary policy communication, and data science. My work integrates macroeconomic theory, empirical analysis, and computational methods to deepen our understanding of financial stability and policy communication.

About
I am currently an Assistant Professor of International Commerce at Sogang University, where I teach courses in international economics, macroeconomics, and finance. I hold a Ph.D.¬†in Public Policy from the KDI School of Public Policy and Management, with a concentration in banking and central banking.
My academic and professional journey spans academia, research, and central banking. Prior to Sogang, I taught economics, research methods, and data science at Woosong University. Before transitioning to academia, I worked at the National Bank of Ukraine, focusing on financial modeling, systemic risk assessment, and banking policy development.
My research explores central bank communication, monetary policy transmission, nonperforming loans, and sustainable finance. I aim to bridge research and policy by integrating empirical analysis with real-world challenges in banking and regulation. I‚Äôve published in peer-reviewed journals and contributed to international economic policy discourse.
I‚Äôm also passionate about using R and Python to promote data-driven decision-making in economics and finance. Through teaching and mentorship, I help students build analytical skills that support both academic inquiry and practical policy implementation.

title: Iegor Vyshnevskyi
text:
I am committed to fostering inclusive, collaborative, and engaging communities within academic and extracurricular settings. My efforts have centered on supporting student well-being, interdisciplinary dialogue, and applied learning across different domains.
As part of my contribution to the growth of computational social science in South Korea, I served as a Teaching Assistant at the inaugural Summer Institute in Computational Social Science (SICSS) in South Korea, co-hosted by KAIST and KDI School in 2022.
I also co-founded and served as the first head of the KDI School Ph.D.¬†Club, helping to establish a peer support network for doctoral students. In parallel, I founded the KDI School Hapkido Club and led efforts to promote physical and mental discipline through martial arts training. I have also volunteered to teach Hapkido to children, encouraging values of respect, teamwork, and perseverance.
These experiences reflect my dedication to nurturing both academic and personal growth within my communities.
